title: Businesses Should Be Wary of Politicization
sub_head: Kimberley Strassel’s “Big Business’s Sharp Left Turn” reminds me of my youth in Maryland where the local lunch counters had signs saying: “We reserve the right to refuse service to anyone.” In the time of Jim Crow laws, everyone knew what that meant.
body:
Kimberley Strassel’s “Big Business’s Sharp Left Turn” (Potomac Watch, Jan. 15) reminds me of my youth in Maryland where the local lunch counters had signs saying: “We reserve the right to refuse service to anyone.” In the time of Jim Crow laws, everyone knew what that meant: unless you were white, you would not receive service at the lunch counter. The argument was that “this is a private business, so we can set our own rules.” The courts finally said something to the effect of, yes, it is a private business, but the doors are open to the general public, therefore you cannot refuse service to any customer because of race. As a result, the lunch counters and other public businesses were integrated.
Sadly, those signs have returned, although not targeting nonwhites at lunch counters, but instead targeting conservatives on social-media platforms, etc. Apparently, conservatives are now being considered an undesirable class of citizens.
As the courts threw out double standards of service for whites versus nonwhites by public, but privately owned, businesses, perhaps there is a legal remedy for the double standard against conservative speech.
Michael R. Johnson
Marlinton, W.Va.
